div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray's Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: FAIZI PASHA AND THE YEMEN.
div.p: The rumour, for which there seems to be some foundation, that Faizi Pasha's position at Sana is one of great difficulty and danger, will be received with regret by all who have follow- ed the course of the Iutest Yemen rebellion. It was in 1892 that' Achmet Faizi Pasha first attained distinction in the campaign against the Yemen rebels led. by Hamid-ed-Din, father of Mahmoud Yahya, the present "Imam" of the Yemen. The rebels fought well, Sanaa was for a time blockaded, and it was only through the efforts of Achmet Faizi that the rebellion was finally crushed in 1894. Mr. Harris, correspondent of the "Times" in Morocco, who made his way to Sana from Aden in disguise, and was eventually arrested and haled before. the Pasha gives.an excellent description of the general in his account of his travels in SE. Arabia, and his statement that Faizi Pasha was the ofie man capable of ruling the Yemen if properly supported has been borne ont by facts. The rebellion died down and for some years the province had rest. Then Achmet Faizi left Arabia to command 'the VIth ' Order (Army Corps) at Baghdad, and the forces of disorder gained strength. No serions rebellion however took place till the winter of 1904 when the Imam Yahya ibn Hamid-ed-Din led the insurgents to a series of victories over the small and ill provisioned 'petits paquets' which Mohamed Riga Pasha, the commander of the Yemen foree, hiad scattered all over the country with an amazing disregard of the first prin- ciples of strategy.

The situation went from Wad to worse. Sand was blockaded and suffered horribly from famine, the soldiers in some instances devour- ing human flesh ; a relieving force was cut to pieces in the passes near Menakhkha and a dejected and starving rabble returned from the surrendered. fortress to Hodeida, Meanwhile war had broken out in the Nejd between the partisans 'of Ibn Sand, the Wahali Emir of Riah, and the Shammar of Hail, under their

Emir, Abd Bl Aziz Ibn Rashid, whom the Turks tegarded as their ally. Ibn Rashid was beaten and called for Turkish aid in November 1904. Achmet Fajizi Pasha set out from Meshed Ali with ten battalions of Turkish soldiers. March- ing over hundreds of miles of desert he reach- ed Hail ar repelled. the Wahabis,"and was negotiating'with their chief when the news reached him of the fall of Sana. Undaunted by heat and fatigue the old general marched over the desert to Medina, and by the end of May had reached Mecca, having crossed the Arabian peninsula with 'slight - loss. From Mecca he matched to Jedda, took "ship to Hodeida\and during: June and July organise the column which was to retake Sana. In the middle of August the troops advanced ani at the beginning of September the Osmanli forces re-entered Sana. The Arabs were unable to face the attacks of disciplined troops and when, in November 1905 the Im had retired into the most inaccessible mountains of the Sada dis- trict, the rebellion. seemed at .an end. But neither Achmet Faizi Pasha nor the Imam hor any foreign observer had counted upon the apathy and mismanagement of the Turkish War Office. 'The troops, unpaid and ill fed, unprovided with clothes and medical comforts began to grow exhausted. The time-expired men were replaced by unwilling recruits from Syria and Kurdistan who were marched in chains from their villages to the depots, and deserted whenéver possible. The ammunition snpplies were not réplenished and Paizi Pasha's appeals for 'reinforcement 'were met by the despatch of criminals, gaol-birds, Te.captured deserters, pressed-men of middle age, and boys who had'not been called for military seryice, What wonder that even the obstinacy of Turkish troops gave way before the constant evidence of callous neglect and criminal want of foresight. Every fever stricken soldier who returned 'to the Asiatic ports of the Ottoman Empire, every sick man who survived the horrors of the 'passage from Hodeida to Suez helped to terrify the Syrians and-Anatolians with his tales of the miseries of the campaign. Every such witness drove the Redifs called oat for service in Yemen toa frenzy of terror, and every transport bound to Hodeida lost men from: desertion|ih the Suez Canal. Bat the advisers of thé' tan could not, or would not, tell the Padishah that the mere despatch of soldiers without uniforms and rifles without ammunition to Sana was aseless : that against a mobile enemy, 2 mobile well trained force thoroughly supplied with eyery essential for a tropical guerilla campaign was needed, and that soldiers even Tarkish soldiers, require food and appreciate good treatment. Matters - grew worse and worse, the wastage outran the supply of reinforcements, and to-day Faizi Pasha with a dispirited and decimated force stands in grave danger of utter defeat."

div.head: Cattle Plague.
div.p: The Fayoum. and,Sharkieh provinces have been-pronounced infected. by cattle plague.

div.head: Sinai Peninsula.
div.p: The.Government has sanctioned a credit of L.E. 1,000 for the making of wells for the water supply of the Sinai Peninsula.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: A fresh case of plague has been reported from Mellawi during the last: 24 hdurs, a recovery.at Deirout, three deaths are reported from Esneh in hospital; a fresh case is reported from Abnoub and two recoveries at Beni Mazar.

div.head: Threat Against Patriarch.
div.p: On Wednesday a Bulgarian book-binder was arrested-by the police, and*a cavass of the Russian Consulate; on suspicion of haying been concerned in the threatening letters sent to the Greek Patriarch of Alexandria, He was, how- ever, set at liberty after examination.

div.head: Fire at Khartoum.
div.p: Mr. Angelo Capato, who arrived yesterday morning from Khartoum, recéived-a telegram in the evening from his manager at Port Sudan informing bim that the whole block of build- ings tn whieh his stores are situated had been destroyed totally by fire. Thetotalloss is about ~£20,000.

div.head: Land in New York.
div.p: Owing to the interest that is being taken in the price of town lands' in Egypt, it may be interesting to notice that a corner plot of land situated at the junction of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-eight street in New York, measuring 25 ft. by 100 ft. has recently been sold for £140,000. This is equal to £56 per square foot or £504 per square yard. This price is a record one even for Fifth Avenue.

div.head: Births and Deaths.
div.p: During the week ending 10th June there were 471 births in the capital of which 10 were Europeans. The deaths 'numbered 759 of which 20 were Europeans: of the Europeans thete were 9 adults and of thé remaining deaths there was the large percentage of 11 European children under five years of age. A small proportion of deaths were due to diptheria and typhoid: measles has contributed a largenumber to the death roll, the balance being due to small-pox and erysipilis.

div.head: CINEMATOGRAPHE URBANORA.
div.p: Parfois tragique, souvent coihique, mais toujours moral, l'Urbanora est la synthése de la vie.

Sa devise si 'connne "We put the :world before you" (Nous placons le monde devant Yous) n'a jamais été plus vraie : chaque semaine figure sur lé programme une vue d'aprés'nature faisant défiler devant les spectatenrs soit un panorama, soit un événement sensationnel, soit tout autre acte ou tranche de la vie qu'il ne Ainsi, les spectacles do' l'Urbanora, au lieu Wetre réservés exclusivement aux enfants, sont deveus non seulement amusants et inte- ressants pour tous, mais instructifs, ce qui ne gate rien, loin de la.

LONDON EXCHANGE ACTIVE.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive, attended by the Goyernor, was present at midday prayers to-day at the Nebi Daniel Mosque.

div.head: BRITISH LABOURERS FOR QUEENSLAND
div.p: Port Said, Thursday.

The Orient liner "Omrah" which arrived here this morning, had on board the first contingent of British labourers for the Queens-. Jand sugar fields: The labourers are to take the place of the Kanaka or South Sea *Island labourers, who haye recently been repatriated under an act of the Australian Commonwealth, passed in pursuance of the White Australia polioy.'To fill the vacancies the Queensland Government have been offering free passages to Australia and a guarantee' of work. In response to this offer many men of a good class have come forward, and those who passed gh the Omrah numbered. 150 exclading their families.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT.
div.p: The final consignment of rails for use in the eonstruction of the Western Oases Railway has been shipped by the Corporation of West- ern Egypt, Limited. Orders haye been placed for passenger rolling stock, and delivery is guaranteed in, good time.

div.head: THE LECHAT GANEM CASE.
div.p: Mr. Chekri Ganem having thallenged Mr. Derroja, Editor of the "Bourse: Egyptienne," to withdraw an article which appeared in that paper in connection with the assault commit- ted on him by M, Lechat or to fight a duel with him by M. Derroja refused to withdraw the article in question and accepted the challenge. A'duel was arranged which was fought with pistols yesterday-at 4.30 p.m. Four rounds were fired but neither party was hit. The seconds of M. Ganém were Captain L. Bourdier and M. Georges Vayssié. Those of M. Derroja were Messrs. J. Verdier and R. Colrat.

div.head: NEW WORK BY PROFESSOR PETRIE.
div.p: It is antiounced that a new work by Profes- shi Flinders Petrie will shartly be published by Messrs Constables This will be entitled "Janns in Modern Life" and is a development: in some measure of his recent Huxley lecture, It deals with questions of race and immigra- tioh, communism, philanthropy, and indivi- dualism in relation to historical philosophy, from a thoroughly modern-point ot view.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB.
div.p: The fifth season of the Alexandria Swimming Club will be opened to-morrow, when the times of members will be taken and % polo match will be played against a team froth H.M.S. "Diana," which is still "ip 'Therelub boat will teave the Marina' for Ras el 'lin lighthouse every Saturday at 3.16 p.m. Members will be glad to learn that a comfortable dressing foom has heen fitted up. The prospects of the club, which improve year by year, thanks té the' energy of the committee in general, and Mr. W. F. Sargeant, Chajmman, and Mr. HS. Martin, Secretary, in particular, and the support which they receive from the yearly increasing number of members, are more brilliant than ever, and we can anticipate a highly successful season. The committee have issued a circular inform- ing the members of the opening of the season to-morrow, and inviting members to bring their friends, expressing the hope that they will turn up in good force,

div.head: AEGYPTICA.
SOME NEW PAPYRI.
div.p: By Joseph Offord.

The evidence afforded by papyri as to Roman law will soon exceed in value all the of the ancient jurists extant, because these documents preserve absolute record of 'the working of the legat enactments in daily life.

Evidence relating to the status of slaves under the Roman dominion in Egypt has been given in "Aegyptiaca" and now referenee will be made to another papyrus' haitiny fron the Fayoum which has 'been "edited"by Sir P. Maunde Thompson for the "Society of Anti- quaries" which illustrates the subject.

This document concerns the sale of a slave to oné Caius Fabullius Macer, an optio upon the Trireme Ligris, a galley of the Misenum fleet, by Quintos Julins Priscuis, a marine, or soldier upon the same vessel. 'The slave was only 7 years old and is named Transfluminiani which title as the 'transaction occurred "at lencia Pieria_npon the Syrian coast, probably refers to: the svar Bapheates, the at the time eastern boundary of the Roman Empire.
The youth's name was Abbas Eytuches, and the price of his transfer was 200 denarii, plus the amount due as, tax upon the import of a slave. The deed ix dated May 24 A.D. 166.

The legal formulae of its contents are inter- esting to jurists and students of Egyptian history, but. it. is important in comparing it with other similar records. to note that the purchaser of the slave «stipulated - for the répayment of the sum disbursed in the event of a'suceessful claim for-restitution "of the slave td some prior owner withopt notice of action for recovery having taken place, being necessary.

Asub-officer. of the Trireime appears as witness to the signatnfes' naméd° C- Julius 'Titianus, It may be that itis to this personage we owe the presence of the papyrus in Egypt and its consequent preservation becanse the Ptefect of that country for . the year 164-166 A.D. was Titus Flavius Titianus who may have been a near relative of C.J. 'Titianus, The statement that in addition to the value of the slave the duty must he paid, (doubtless because' the boy was just imported) remind one of the long list of import duties found at Coptos by Dr. Flinders Petrie which. together with the lengthy inscription kriow as "The Tariff of Palmyra form our chief authorities for the "Douane" of the Romans.

This is not the only Egyptian papyrus concerned: with: sailors" in the celebrated Misennm fleet,'whose naval base was just north of Naples, for among the hundreds of Oxyrahyn- chus papyri is one containing a letter from a young marine from Egypt who had jus been enrolled in this fleet. The text which is quite legible: and. complete, shows that?the young warrior was' writing from Italy to his father in Egypt.

"Apion to Epemachus, his father a lord; a thousand times salutation. Before all I trust that you are well, and be you happy, yoo ard sister, her daughter and my brother. I give thanks "to the lord Sarapis that I am preserved:from the dangers of the voyage. Upon reaching Misenum I have reeeived for the expenses of the road, from the Emperor, 3 gold pieces, and I am going on well. I pray you lori father write to me a few words, first to tell me of your health, Second as to that of my brother and)-sister, thirdly because I adore thy hand, becanse you so well educated me that it will soon procure me promotion; I hope ;if the gods permit."
"Embrace vigorously Capitan, my brother, and-mny sister ; and Serenilla ; and my friends. My name (his new one as a sailor) is Antonins Maximus, I wish you good health. The centary of Athenocus."
It appears probable that the inditing of this letter, i much to the greeting.to-a certain Serérilta-but it is a most interesting specimen of the similarity of human life many centuries ago.

div.head: GERMAN TRAMP NUISANCE.
div.p: To the editor of the "Egyptian Gazette"

Sir.— My trips to: Cairo, Tautah, ete. have brought me too frequently into. unpleasant contact with many German. tramps. 'There may be 100 in Cairo alogie. They are lazy, uséless 'rascals, apparently * belonging to, some begging organization. By theit sudden /bold- "ness and threat fn' dark 'ot lonély plaves they "terrorize ladies and you! nd are @ soufce 'of real danger, Since tou igts departed, many have invaded Alexandria and other citiés of Egypt. I have personal knowledge of some 15 jocally and: have witnessed, 7 of them together at 8 o'clock at night, meaning violenge_ to §eme one givén opportunity as per the high- way robbery on the new promenade reported not long'since in your paper.

'To day wasthe third time ina week'that Iwas accosted by' the scoundrels, J was at lunch When he shuffled' up, a-youug' well «fed fellow and -began his usual tale of woe— "long walk from Port Said" and so on,-I heard of 20 'times before. As usual I- promptly told- him to vanish, and mistaking me for an Englishman he at once opened a torrent of abuse about the British fldg and what loyal Germans would dowith itete., ete. Waitersinter- fered uselessly till "The—Englishman" (I am worse as I come from. , Connaught !)) moved from his table and about fractured his jaw, thus suddenly stopping all reference to flags of any sort:

In a moment he picked himself up and disappeared, giving us all a rest. The question is how long are the German authorities going to permit this scum organization to annoy, pester, and insult us. It has lasted quite long énough, and places one between the devil and deep sea, as the British Consal -says never to take the law into your own hands, so 'I don't see how one is expected to travel a couple of miles any time to report the insulting conduct of a tramp, and babyishly. claim doubtfal pro- tection and "shere where's the satisfaction at all, at all" if the Kaiser's scarecrow subject sat down in my absence and finished my dinner !

Having an extensive and intimate German agquaintanceship in Egypt I am perfectly certain I but* voice the wishes of every lady and gentlenian 'of this nationality, who will coincide in wishing their too numerous local sealiwag compatriots well beyond the bounda- ries of mneh abased Egypt.
I am, Sir, C. W. A. N. Shillilagh Castle, Alexandria, June 13th 1907.

div.head: POLICE DOG SERVICE.
div.p: To the editor of the "Egyptian Gazette"

Dear Sir, — I should like, Mr. Editor, to tell your readers who own dogs to keep them in irons or as nearly so as possible. The police it appears, in what passes for wisdom at the Gouvernorat, have passed a resolution that dogs without ¢muzzles must snffer the last penalty ot the'law. Thepoor man in the street (i.e. shawish) was instiucted to remember the traditions of his race and do his duty. Asa matter of fact he did no such thing at all. .He was probably afraid of the dogs he was sup- posed to catch... At any rate, a special force of our valiant police was told off for the purpose of cornering anything in the likeness of a dog. Discretion of course had no*place in their instructions. For the information of strangers in'the country it should be 'stated that the Egyptian shawish is so naturally discreet (especially 'when it is a choice with valour) that his superiors scarcely ever find it necessary to warn him. not to be too zealous in the execution of his duty. Dogs, all and sundry, in the unmuzzled* state 'must die the death. Now; Mf. Editor, I have a dog, a small dog—a minature in fact. He (or she rather) is'so very small that it is quite impossible to finda muzzle in the whole of Egypt te'fit her tiny head. Of a' morning I take her out for a short airing, and she follows docilely at my heels. This morning F followed my usual habit, and was on 'the point of re-entering my own door, when, turning, I saw a petson wear- ing no uniform strike my microscopic pup around the loins with a.kourbash that' wound itself round and round the tiny body, while the poor brate howled in-terror. I; of course, rose to the occasion, and then two police (i.e. special force) came up and explained the situa- tion. The explanation beitig in Arabie, I could not understand one word. At any rate in spite of my' protests, the proxiniity to my owt doorway, and the manifest harmlessness of the dog, shé 'was placed 'in a wagon 'special- ly constructed for small dogs, and taken to a place whieh I-subsequently found labelled, inrather delicate irony, "Infirmary: Preveri- tion of Crueltyto Animals." Later'I visited the Gouvérnorat, was received with courtesy, told mj little story, waited two whole hours, gave a native clerk upon demand = minate history of my life from the date of leaving school, which he embodied ii" procés-verbal, waited another hour, paid P.T. 30, and was then told I should probably have no difficulty in getting back my dog As a matter of fact with- in three or four hours of reaching the Gouver- norat I found myself in possession of something written in Arabic and was directed vaguely to take the paper to Boulac. Before receiving this paper I had signed several formidable looking documents, and in a half dazed way was wondering whether I had come to be tried for my lfe or simply to obtain permission to withdraw a small pup from confinement. Well Mr. Editor, I went to Boulac, and in the course of my visit to this delectable district of

Cairo, I learned in how many places stray dogs may be kept. There are three at least and each is situated inthe most out of the way locality ohe'could possibly select. Exploring Boulac for a small dog is like searching for pins in the Catacombs. However, after several' hours search in a blazing sun, I found my. very small pup and the re-union wasa touching, one.

My object in relating: the outline of this Serious domestic comedy is to remind your. esteemed readers (1) not to "have dogs 3 (2) to keep them in the cellar or the ice chest 3 (8) to expect nothing in the way of rudimentary common: from anything that wears a police' uniform. While in Cairo great savage' baboons nose their way untiazzled along the most crowded thoroughfares, and pariah' of mongrel size gambol quite un muzzledin the most frequented down streets under the eyes of our model police force; a special service, be it remarked, is instituted to entrap small pet house-dogs travelling quietly at the heels of their masters in the outlying and deserted sectins of the city. To draw a moral, would I fear onl ywaste more of your valuable spece. Thanking you in anticipation.
Yours truly,
Canis Major.
Cairo, June 11 1907.

div.head: H.M.S. "DIANA".
SAILING RACES.
div.p: On Wednesday last every boat belonging to H.M.S. "Diana" started for the weekly sailing race, the Khedial Yacht Club having mosted kindly offered a cup fo rthe boat with the largest number of points at the conclusion of the "Diana's" stay at Alexandria. The course selected was triangular, viz cross line, elbow buoy, Gabbary buoy, cross line, 3 times round, being just over 9 miles,

The service official handieap worked out well as faras the pinnace and whaler -were concerned, . the larger boat winning by 8 mypates, the whaler having been penalised 6) mihutes for winning last week. The wind was not fresh enough to suit the cutters but these' 3 boats had a great race for 3rd. place, 2 minites separating the Ist and 3rd. The follow- ing shows the result of thé racing -—
Boat . Sailed by Handicap Time p.m.
Pinnace. Lieut. James 39 m, 4.35,
Whaler. Petty Officer Grady scratch 4.46
Cutter. Lient. Smyth-Osbonrne $2 m. 4 50

The pinnace and whaler are now equal with 7. points each. The racing next week should prove exciting between the whaler and pinnace as the latter is now penialised nother 6 minutes and' will have to allow the whaler 47 minotes, but possibly the galley, which this time'was late in starting, may upset these calculations.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL COTTON CONGRESS.
PACKING OF EGYPTIAN YARNS.
div.p: Mr. C. W. Macara, chairman. of the Inter- national Federation in the Cotton Industry, on his retarn to England from the cotton congress at Vienna, made a statement, in whivh he said that the constitution of the congress was re- markable. _ Japan waS now added to the subscribing countries, and there weré present representative men from nearly all the cotton- using countries of Europe and from India, offti- cials of the railway companies of the Southern States of America, the head of the Cotton} Department of the United. States Statistical Buréau, and the presidents of the asstdiations of American planters. The federation specially welcdmed these last-named gentlemen, because for many years European spinners have felt that they have had serious ground compla- int arising from the condition of the cotton balés that come across the Atlantic, and they are not without hope that the means of removing the evils complained of can be devised by personal intercourse.

The chief causes of complaint are that the staple is injured during the process of separat- ing the reed from the lint (technically termed ginning) that the covering of the 'cotton is unsuitable and incapable of retaining the distinctive marks that are lightly pressed upong it, and that the cotton is insufficiently com- pressed, being little more than half the density of an Egyptian bale, with the result that the cost of carriage is seriously increased.

Among the planters' difficulties are included the handicaps imposed by various trusts which control the bagging, the binding, and the com-. pressing of the cotton, which trusts. cannot ineet with energetic support from their eus- temers, the spinners of the world. From the spirit prevailing throughout the Vienna Con- gress it was obvious that this support they will bave to the fullest extent. A large party of European spinners, probably numbering between 50 and 100, intend to make a tour of the Southern States of America fo rthe pur- pose fo cementing the closer relationships that are springing up between them and the cotton-growers, and they will attend the spin- ners and planters' Convention in Alabama in October next, where they will have the advan- tage of conferring not only with the planteres, but iwth th espinners and manufactureres of America. Mr. Macara added that it shoudl not be forgotten efforts should be made to grow cotton in every part of the world in which it can be grown advantageously.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Fahkry Pasha has arrived at Alexandria from Cairo.
Riaz Pasha has left for Europe.
Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha will inspect the 4th Battalion of the Egyptian Army to-morrow morning, prior to leaving for England by the Austrian Lloyd mail boat.
Naoum Bey Shoukair, has returned to Cairo from kantara.
Boghos Pasha Nubar and Neguib Bey Ghali have left for Europe.
Count Bressler Rayski, recently appointed first secretary to the German Agency, will arrive at Alexandria on Monday, and will act as Agent during the absence of Count Bernstoff.
Mr. and Miss Manley have left Alexandria for England, where they will pass the summer.
Mr. Wanderlich, German Consul at Alex-andria, has left for Europe
Mr. Kozibrodski, Austro-Hungarian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General, will leave for Europe on the 26th inst.
Mr. And Mrs. H. Barker have left England.

div.head: THE ABBAS THEATRE.
div.p: The Lombard troupe are a brilliant successs and the variety of the programme has more than justified this success. During the last week four different operettas have been pre- sented namely "Dalla Terra alla Luna," "II Diavolo in Corpo" "La Cicala e la Formica," and "santarellna," all with excellent "mise en scene" and well chosen costumes. The Sisters Rosalin are the idols of the "gods" and meet with more than flattering attention, which is richly deserved, but it is to be hoped that they will have an opportunity of taking some rest, as the calls upon thei rabilities must entail very considerable fatigue: such, however is the price of popularity. Madame Calligaris has proved herself an excellent comedienne and her elocution is especially pleasing. Madame Baldi, and Mr. Fanani, tenor, both deserve mentoni and the Urbano has only to show himsel fon the stage to evoke ripples of mirth. Madame COlombo is, unfortunately conspicuous by her absence, which is to be regretted in view of her excellent work in "Boccacio." On Wednesday the "Geisha" was presented and the performance met with well merited success. enhanced by the fact of teh respresentation being a benefit for the Sisters Rosalin.

Ici, la séance-de ce Basin a été, sans edn: teste, moins morose que celles des+denx jours précédents. Elle a €té méme non-seulement gaie, mais encore anique en son genre, Tout | dabord, aprés avoir longuement délibéré sur Jes moyens propres A améliorer la situation (en corbeille s'entend) le Comité de I'honorable Corporation des agents de change du Caire avait fini par décider, hier soir, de réduire, jusqu'a nonvel ordre, la durée' des séances une heure, au lieu de deux. Ce matin, il y eut changement de dispositions, le Comité de' la Bourse d'Alexandrie 'ayantopté pour unedemi- heure. I] fut conséquemment résolu- qa'on eee les affaires entre oh heures et. 11 h. 30.

or a onze heures sonnantes, la séance a été ouverte, rion par des offres ou'es- demandes, mais bien par des discours drdlatiques, dans lesquels il était question de tout et de diverses autres choses. On prétend, il est vrai, que des propositions extrémement intéressantesauraient eté Gmises pour remédier a la crise ; aussi bien il est navrant qu'elles se soient. perdues dans 'la confusion et le brouhaha. Toujours est-il qu'une motion tendant a proclamey la gréve,a mettre la clef'sous la porte, pour forcer la main a la haute banque, n'a pas été agréde, Dautres propositions " ejusdem farine " ont eu leméme sort. Ce n'est assurément pas regrettable, car ce qu'il y aurait peut-@tre de mieux a faire serait de laisser les choses suivre leur cours naturel, maintenant surtout: qu'un dénougment ne saurait tarder.. En agissant autrement on provoquerait une, véritable pa- nique.

An dernier moment, uné démonstration a été projetée osntre le Crédit Lyonnais, - dont *Pattitude dans la phase difficile que traverse le marché financier égyptien est de plus en plus sévérement jugée ; mais, vu l'heure ayancée, la manifestation aurait été remise A un autre jour.

En attendant, on n'a guére travaillé en cor: beille, et aprés,la cléture de. cette séance mé- miorable, la commission de'la cote a décitlé tte' n'inserire que deux changements an tableau officiel de la Corporation : la National Bank a £ 21 et Agricole 4 7 11/16-3/4,

div.head: SOCIETE INTERNATIONALE DES EMPLOYES D'ALEXANDRIE.
div.p: La Société Internationale des Employés d'Alexandrie vient de prendre l'initiative d'une protestation contre la Compagnie dés Eaux. Voici la lettre que le comiténous adresse A ce sujet:

"Nous avons remarqué que, par suite de l'augmentation constante des loyers, la compa- gnie des Eaux, basant gon tarif Sur les con- trats, bénéficie d'une plus-value, sans que pour 'cela la consonimation d'un ménage soit changée.

"Nous ayoris pensé que représentant pliis de 800 ménages, nous pourrions, en nous adressant a diverses autres sociétés de la Ville, réuuir les intéréts de 1500 a 2000 familles, ce qui est une foree appréciable.
"Notre société a done détidé de prendre ljnitiative d'une réunion de tous les groupe- ments d'Alexandrie, qui aurait. lieu le dimanche matin 30 Juin, A 9 heures, a» notre siége social."

En vertu ing ddeision Générale Extraontinaine du 57 ef ('Antorivation. Minintérielle da 23 Mai 190 Jo Connell d'Adininintration Anonyme dow Baox (ly Caire émet, en augmen® tation Mos 272,000 -Actions de Jouissance aotuolloment oxintantos, tronte mille Actions do Jouisiance nouvellés, dont la souscription Oat rdsorvde Aux-portoura d*Actions actuelles do Capital ou do" Jouinance indistinctement, sur la base guns Avtion nouvelle pour onze Actions actuellea vain attribution' de fraction.(*)

Ces nouvelles Actions de Jouissance auront les memes droits que celles actuellement existan- tes, sous cette seile reserve qu, devant etre libereees pour cette annee, suivant les conditions ci-apres, de moitie seolement de leur prix d'emission et a la date du 1er Juillet, elles n'auront droit, comme dividende de l'exercise.
* Extrait des Statuts :
Art. 6.-Le capital social est de huit mil- lions cinq cent mille francs, et divise en soixante huit mille actions de cent vingt cinq francs chacune, dites "actions de capital."
Art. 13.-Independaurement des 68,000 ac- tions de capital mentionnes ci-dessus a l'art.6, il est cree 272,000 actions de jouissance sans valeur nominale.
Chaque action de capital donne droit a l'interet de 4% et au remboursement, specifies aux articles 20 et 21 ci-apres.

div.head:
AMERICA AND JAPAN.
JAPANESE PRESS WARNED.

div.p: The Press has been officially advised to abstain from the publication of inflamatory matter regarding the American question.. (R.)
Eight political-prisoners have been shot for participation in the. Riga' mutiny of '14th April.(Reuter )
'The 'T'sar has received an envoy from Mene- lik, from whom he has accepted presents. (R.)
'The Russo-Japanese agreement ~ regarding the working of:Chinese on Eastern and South Manchurian railways has been signed.( Reuter)
Insurgents' attacked the village of Yung- chang, in the Prefecture of Wai-chow, and burnt the military yamen and salt station. 'The provincial force _pufsued and engaged. the rebels. (Reuter)

div.head:
FRANCE AND JAPAN.
CHAMBER OF DEPUTIES.

div.p: M. PichotArnounced that it, has" been proposed" by Japan' that a simultaneous publication in Paris and Tokio of the Franco- Japanese) agreement, should take place. on Monday. (Reuter,)

The trial of those implicated in the plot to assassinate the King and Queen on_ their wedding-day has been concluded. The journal- ist Nakens, who assisted Moral to leave Ma- urid, and two others have been sentenced to 9 years' imprisonment. The rest have been acquitted. (Reuter)
80 more municipalities resigned yesterday evening. (Reuter)
General Picquart has ordered an enquiry into the mutiny of soldiers of 100th line, who refused to oppose the wine-growers. (Havas)
Salar-ed-Dowleh ahs fled towards Mendeli, the residence of his father-in-law. The loyalists are in hot pursuit. (Reuter)
Messrs. Falliéres, Clemenceau, and Thomp- son have left for Cherbourg to meet the Danish Sovereigns. (Havas)
The "Novoi Vremia" contradicts the ramour of a change of Cabinet. (Havas)

The Foreign Minister, M. [ y; speaking before the Budget Committee, said that the treaty of Portsmouth was regarded originally as a temporary tru¢e, but that view was now changed. He had a firm belief in the stability of the peaceful relations existing between Russia and Japan. (Reuter)

div.head: PORTE'S FINANCIAL TROUBLES.
RAISING FUNDS BY MORTGAGING REVENUES.
div.p: The Constantinople correspondent of the "Times" sends to that journal an interesting communication describing the embarrassed financial position of Turkey at the present time.

Thongh their failure may already be pre- dicted, the negotiations between the Porte and the Deutsche Orient Bank for an advance of £1300,000 haye, he says, been interesting from more than one. point. of view. The money is needed to pay Krupps for guns and munitions furnished by them to the "Turkish Govern- nient, and will be repaid 'out of the revenues of the military armaments fund. As the fund is comparatively well administered the security is soufid enough; the Deutsche Orient Bank is naturally anxious to: complete the transac- tion, ghich will bring it 7 per cent. interest on the capital advanced,

The Governnient, which for many years past has not been in such desperate straits for jnoney as it is at present, is equally eager. 'The difficulties in the way are due to the oppo- sition of the Ottoman Bank" and the Deutsche Bank, which, working together, have hitherto enjoyed a. practical monopoly of loans and advances to the Porte. 'These two establish- ments are so influential both at the Palace and at the Porte that, although it is to the obvious Interest of the 'State to break down their mo- nopoly, the attempt is foredoomed to failure. It-is worth noting that their co-operation does not seem -to be sd'elose as it once was. After the agreement of May, 1899, they worked most cordially together, especially with regard to the railways, and they" participated on equal terms, taking each 35 per cent. of the shares in the Baghdad : Railway enterprise, which promised them a rich reward in the shape of profits on construction loans and the excess of the kilometric guarantees over work- Jug_expenses. During the. winter of 1904-5 they had a serious quarrel, arising*out of the competition ot French manufacturers with Krupps for the supply of guns to the Turkish army. It was, however, the Turks who paid the'damage, in the shape of heavy charges for unnecessary loans and for kilometrie guarantees on needless railway lines, and it is, therefore, doubtful whether the quarrel-caused any real.estrangement between the banks.

But tlie Ottoman Bank has recently ceasetl to take the same interest as formerly in the Baghdad Railway, whether in deference to the whcomprontising attitude of the French Govern- ment, or because it recognizes that the finances of 'Turkey are in no position to stend the strain' which would be imposed upon them by the continuation of the line on the exorbitant terms laid down in+the convention. A few weeks ago, on the failure of the negotiations for a loan of £T__2,000,000 to be guaranteed on the receipt of the Lighthouse Company, it advanced: £ T. 200,000 to the Porte, to be repaid out of the Government's share of the excess of the revenues ceded to the Public Debt by the decree of Muharrem. This exces' is now ear-marked upto July, 1910; and the action of the Ottoman Bank has greatly annoyed the Germans who look to this revenue to finance the Baghdad Railways. As sooh as the tfarisaction bseame known the German Ambassador protested against it to the Snitan, and the Grand Vizier was attacked in the German Press forMisshare in it. The purchase of the Constantinople Quay shares by the Ottoman Bank'and the Bank of England can hardly have been more agreeable to the Germaiinanciers.

Another significant point is the readiness which the Turkish Government has again dis- played to raise ready. money by mortgaging its revenues. The extent.to which this has been carried is one of the most potent causes of the preserit embarrassed state of the Treasury. So large a proportion of the Government's income is pledged for the repayment of loans, c., 'that the remainder is utterly inadequate to sarry. on the ordinary administration of the éountry. It is, of course, always the best and most regular revenues which are alienated in this way, so that it may be said without much exaggeration that the Governnient tiow has full control only of those revenues which foreign financiers do not-regard as sufficiently good security on whith tolend money. If, as is hoped, the 3 per cefit. Customs surtax comes into force on June 25, it' will bring a mueh- needed relief. But, even/so, the financial state of the country will remain very serious, espe cially as there is every reason to expect that

the harvest will be considerably below the average. This will be a double loss to the Go- dvernment. It loses by the falling off in the tithes, and by the increase in the amounts which it will have to pay to the railway com- panies in kilometric guarantees to make good the decrease in their receipts. The only people who stand to gain by a bad harvest are the shareholders of the guaranteed railways. By the kilometric guarantee system, which must be considered a standing proof of the inability of Turkish statesmen to cope with European financiers, these undertakings make the greatest profit when they do the least work. The smal- ler their traffic the less they spend in working expenses, while the decline in their receipts is made up by the guarantees paid by a generous, if not very intelligent, Governmétit.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: 'The Sirdar has just completed twenty one years continuous service in connection with the Egyptian Army, having been appointed to it.on the last day of May, 1886, but prior to that he was attached to the Khedive's from 1882 to 1885. When he first donned the fez, little did the young gunner dream of the brilliant and useful fature in store for him.

Owing to an unexpected hitch between thé naval and military authorities with respect to the transfer of Lieutenant Franklin from the post of Director of Music to the Egyptian Army to that of Director of the Royal Naval School of Music, Eastleigh. the appointment of Mr. F, Ferguson, bandmaster of the Ist King's Dragoon Guards, Hounslow, to the first named post has not yet been formally confirmed.

In September next, Captain G. M. Hannay, King's Own Scottish Borderers, will "complete his three years' tenure in the adjutancy of the 3rd Battalion, and will revert to regimental duty if not? granted an extension in: the interim

Captain J. G. R. Walsh, Royal Berkshire Regiment, who commanded a company in the 2nd Battalion during a portion of its recent stay at Alexandria, has just been promoted Major in the Ist Battalion at Dublin, in succession to the late Major Harcourt Taylor, whose stidden death occurred lately.

Colonel R. C. C, Cox, commanding the 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling. Fusiliers will vacate that berth early in the, coming year, The step should "go to Major H. 0. D. Hick- man, second th command of the 1st Battalion in Crete.

The-following additions are to be made to the ordinary rates of the regimental daily pay of lieutenant colonels of the undermentioned arms of the service—with effect from the Ist April last—Honsehold Cavalry, 1s ; Cavalry of the Line, 8s ; Royal Field Artillery, 5s; Royal-Garrison Artillery, 1s 6d ; Infantry of the Lie5s ; lieutenant colonel commanding a batfalion of the West India Regiment, 3s ; and lieutenant colonel commanding the West African Regiment, 3s. Apparently the lieutenant "colonels enjoy the money saved by the wiping out of the seconds in command, whi is another of Mr. Haldane's economies
Lieutenant W. W. Gillam, Royal Field Artillery, has been selected for service with the King's African Rifles.
The whole of the R.G.A., Royal Engineers, and Army Service Corps are to be re-armed forthwith with the short rifle.

The Army Council has issued instructions that 13 and 18 pounder QF. and 60 pounder B.L. guns gre not to be photographed except at distancés which would prevent anything more than a general view of them being re- produced, and that persons, other than sol- diers and officers of the Crown - or other per- ons duly authorised are not tobe allowed to bein the battery while practice is being carried out. Officers of foreign ~ armies who have special permission from the War Office may be permitted to witness. practice, but they will not be allowed to handle equipment, nor will information, except of a general nature, be imparted to them concerning the equipment and methods of fire discipline,

It has been the practice of recent years to arm dismounted Warrant Officers and Staff Sergeants, with a 'carbine, in order that, in action, they. may be\rendered practically. in- distinguishablé from the rank and file. The great coat, however, which is carried en bande- role appears to/ afford aready mark of distine- tion, 'which quite nullifies the carriage of the carbine, and the Army Council is accordingly considering the advisability of abolishing the order contained in paragraph 1962, King's Regulations, that great coats should be carried en bandrole by Warrant Officers and Staff Officers of dismounted units, and sub- stituting a regulation that they should carry their great voats on the back, in 9 coat carrier.
Captain W. C. Pakerhan, who commanded the cruiser Venus when she was guardship off Alexandria, has been appointed to the com- mand of the first class' armoured cruiser Antrim.

div.head: PERSIAN MAHOMEDSNS AND CHRISTIANITY.
div.p: Sir Andrew Wingate, and afterwards Lord Kinnaird, presided at Exeter-hall last week over the annual meeting of the Bible Lands Missions Aid Society, which subsidises missions, chiefly American, in the' Levant. Dr. Cohen, of Urumia, said that the American Presbyter- ians had been at work for 74 years, chiefly among the Nestorians, or Syrian Chistians, in the hope of ulti ly reaching Mahomedans through them. He believed the great battle between Christianity and Islam would be fought in Persia. The Persians were more liberal and simple than the Turkish Mahomedans, and he had never experienced opposition or discourtesy from them. There were 400 Mahomedan boys and girls in the mission schools. The open conyerts from Mahome- danism, were not "many, but they included men Tike the young Kurd physician who always prayed inf Christ's name before treating acase, and the Sheikh, with 25,000 Kurds under him, who had been baptized and who exercised a wonderful influence in his villages. He believed there were thouginds of secret believers, only waiting for religious liberty. The Persian Constitution had come to stay, and religions liberty was probably not far off: One of the chief Mahomedan ecclesiastics had imformed him that he and others believed religious liberty was according to God's will, and they were working for it; though they had to. go,carefully owing to the fanaticism of others. The mission, Dr. Cohen added, had about 4,000 children in 200 schools. 'The Rey. Dr. G.E. White, of Pontus, said that the American missionaries were wholly supported from America, the British contribution sap- porting native agents.

div.head: COTTON WAGES DISPUTE.
div.p: The Federation of Master Cotton Spinners' Associations decided las Thursday, after con- ference at Manchester with representatives of the Operatives' Association, to grant an ad- vance of 5 per cent in wages as from the third pay day in this month, to spinners, card and blowing room hands, reelers, and winders. The advance will benefit about 120,000 workpeople.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de lEtat Egyptien
AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins'de Fer de T'Etat a Vhonneur de porter a la connaissance da Public qu'elle recevra jusqu'au vingt juin prochain, 4 midi au plus tard, des offres pour la fourniture de balais en "Samar," soit 10,000 (dix-mille) ¢mmanchés: et 3,000 (trois-mille) | sans manches, Des échantillons devront ¢tre soumis en méme temps que les offres. La li- yraison sera faite franco dans les Magasins de |' VAdministration 4-Gabbary (Alexandrie). Les Conditions Generales de cette fourniture peu- vent etre consultees au Bureau Central du Service des Magasins 4 Boulac (Caire), et aux Magasins de Gabbary (Alexandrie) tous les jours de neaf heures da matin 4 une heure p.m. les Dimanches et jours fériés exeeptés.

Un quart de la quantité des balais emman- chés est a livrer immédiatement ; un - quart dela quantité totale des balais emmanchés et de ceux sans manches est a livrerdans deux mois et le reste sera livré-quatre mois aprés la commande,

Pour étre admis a concourir, le soumission- naire devra yerser, au préalable, a la Caisse de Administration, 4 'titre de dépdt provi- soire, une somme de-L.E. 20 (livres Egyptien- nes vingt). Le soumissionnaire déclaré adjudi- cataire devra parfaire cette somme jusqu'a concurrence du 10 % (dix pour cent) da mon- tant de loftre agréée.

Les offres devront étre accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de trente milliémes ainsi que du reca constatant le .versement du cautionnement provisoire susvisé. Elles seront adressées par la Poste sous pli recom- mandé a :
Monsieur le Directeur Général des Chemins de Fer del'Etat Le Caire.
et sous double enveloppe, V'tatérieure portant la suscription suiyante : "Offre pour Fourniae de Balais."
L'Administration ne siengage pas a accep- ter fire la plus basse, ni. 4 donner suite aux soumissions présentées. Elle se réserve le droit de diviser la commande,
